docs.lead_paragraph: It was the cacophony of imagined voices that finally caused Priscilla Pierce to snap. That was in July 1973. ''I felt like I was going crazy,'' Ms. Pierce, now 62, said recently at her mobile home in Greenville, in Orange County, N.Y.

headline.main: The Neediest Cases; A Fragile Disposition in a Rickety Home

docs.abstract: Woman with bipolar disorder and schizophrenia gets help from Catholic Charities of the Archdiocess of New York, one of seven beneficiaries of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund; photo (M)
docs.snippet: It was the cacophony of imagined voices that finally caused Priscilla Pierce to snap. That was in July 1973.    ''I felt like I was going crazy,'' Ms. Pierce, now 62, said recently at her mobile home in Greenville, in Orange County, N.Y.

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: NEW YORK TIMES NEEDIEST CASES FUND

docs.lead_paragraph: Gov. George E. Pataki's top budget advisers are considering a plan that would require the state to pick up a larger share of the skyrocketing Medicaid costs now being paid by localities, according to administration officials. Medicaid, a $42 billion-a-year health insurance program for the state's three million low-income and poor residents, is the fastest growing part of the state's $100 billion annual budget, state officials say. Its costs are shared by state and local governments in New York, as well as by the federal government.

headline.main: State May Pay Larger Share Of Medicaid

docs.abstract: Gov George Pataki's budget advisers consider plan to require New York State to pick up larger share of skyrocketing Medicaid costs now being paid by municipalities; proposal would build on Senate Republicans' plan to rein in certain state-mandated benefits (S)
docs.snippet: ALBANY, Jan. 4 - Gov. George E. Pataki's top budget advisers are considering a plan that would require the state to pick up a larger share of the skyrocketing Medicaid costs now being paid by localities, according to administration officials.

byline.original: By AL BAKER and RAYMOND HERNANDEZ

docs.lead_paragraph: Experts retained by the Bush administration said on Tuesday that more effective disciplining of incompetent doctors could significantly alleviate the problem of medical malpractice litigation. As President Bush prepared to head to Illinois on Wednesday to campaign for limits on malpractice lawsuits, the experts said that states should first identify those doctors most likely to make mistakes that injure patients and lead to lawsuits.

headline.main: Panel Seeks Better Disciplining of Doctors

docs.abstract: Experts retained by Bush administration say more effective disciplining of incompetent doctors could significantly alleviate problem of medical malpractice litigation; focus on doctor discipline is noteworthy because Pres Bush has sided with doctors against plaintiffs' lawyers and is preparing to campaign for national limits on malpractice lawsuits (M)
docs.snippet: Experts retained by the Bush administration said on Tuesday that more effective disciplining of incompetent doctors could alleviate the problem of medical malpractice litigation.

docs.lead_paragraph: Two weeks after bus workers in Queens and Brooklyn staged a sickout and a work slowdown to protest their lack of a contract, New York City officials have made little headway in resolving labor issues that have hampered the Bloomberg administration's plan to have the Metropolitan Transportation Authority take control of seven private bus companies. The sickout and the slowdown, which were not officially authorized, lasted only a few days, but they affected 70,000 riders in the two boroughs. Union officials have warned that a full-scale strike could begin any day now.

headline.main: City's Plan to Acquire Bus Lines Is Mired in Labor Issues

docs.abstract: New York City's plan for Metropolitan Transportation Authority to take control of private bus companies is hampered by stalled contract disputes with six of seven bus lines; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Officials have made little headway in resolving labor issues that have hampered a plan to have the Metropolitan Transportation Authority take control of seven private bus companies.

docs.lead_paragraph: A federal advisory panel, working closely with the Bush administration, announced a list of 146 types of prescription drugs on Monday that should be covered under Medicare's new drug benefit. The panel, the United States Pharmacopeia, a venerable organization that sets standards for the pharmaceutical industry, said prescription drug plans should offer beneficiaries at least two drugs of each type. Insurers that follow the recommendations will be presumed to meet one of the major criteria in the new Medicare law.

headline.main: Advisory Panel Lists Drugs It Wants New Law to Cover

docs.abstract: Federal advisory panel working closely with Bush administration announces list of 146 types of prescription drugs that should be covered under Medicare's new drug benefit; insurers that follow its recommendations will be presumed to meet one of major criteria in new Medicare law; some patient advocates say guidelines do not guarantee coverage for new costly effective drugs that might be needed to treat certain conditions; guidelines appear to come down in favor of insurers, who seek to limit number and types of drugs, more than drug companies, that want as many drugs as possible on list (M)
docs.snippet: A federal panel, working closely with the Bush administration, announced a list of 146 types of prescription drugs that should be covered under Medicare's new drug benefit.

docs.lead_paragraph: Representative Robert T. Matsui, a California Democrat who spent his early childhood in internment camps for Japanese-Americans and served for 26 years in the House, died Saturday night at the National Naval Medical Center in Bethesda, Md. He was 63. The cause of death was pneumonia linked to a rare bone-marrow disease, myelodysplastic disorder, according to a statement released Sunday by his office. He had been in the hospital since Dec. 24.
docs.abstract: Representative Robert T Matsui dies at age 63; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Representative Robert T. Matsui, a Democrat of California, spent his early childhood in internment camps for Japanese-Americans.

docs.lead_paragraph: With Republicans here emboldened by the November election results, members of New York's heavily Democratic delegation on Capitol Hill are worried that they will be shoved to the margins when Congress returns this month to confront a host of issues that will have a direct impact on the city and state. Conservative lawmakers, vowing to make bigger spending cuts this year than they ever did in President Bush's first term, are already eyeing some top priorities of local and state politicians, including federal money for hospitals, nursing homes, mass transportation projects and homeland security initiatives. As a result, members of the delegation say, the battles will be intense.

headline.main: Pie Shrinking, New Yorkers in Congress Fight for Their Slice

docs.abstract: New York State's heavily Democratic delegation fears election results that put four more Republican seats in Senate and five more in House will lead to tougher battles over spending on local and state level and that New York Democrats will not have strength in numbers to fight Republican-controlled Congress (M)
docs.snippet: Members of New York's heavily Democratic delegation on Capitol Hill worry they will be shoved aside when Congress returns to confront issues that impact the city and state.

docs.lead_paragraph: CREIGHTON QUINN was pensive as he took a break last Tuesday from the morning paper and his plate of eggs at a Hartford diner. The night before, the 47-year-old account executive learned that Governor M. Jodi Rell had undergone surgery for breast cancer and would be in the hospital for three days. Mr. Quinn said he wished he'd had some advance notice. ''I was shocked,'' he said. ''You didn't hear anything and then all of a sudden, she's having an operation.'' That's the way Mrs. Rell wanted it.

headline.main: By Governor's Order, Do Not Make a Fuss

docs.abstract: Connecticut Gov M Jodi Rell, who quietly checked into Danbury Hospital to undergo mastectomy and reconstructive surgery, sends message asking people not to send cards, flowers or gifts during her brief hospital stay; political observers speculate that Rell underplayed her illness to head off claims that she will be distracted from leading state by her recovery; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: ''Mr. Levy's First Year'' (editorial, Dec. 26) chastises Steve Levy, the Suffolk County executive, on his effort to enforce the law by cracking down on illegal immigration, saying ''it's a solution in search of a problem.'' Yet in the same issue the article ''East End Hospitals Seek Taxpayer Help'' tells about the financial straits of three East End hospitals due partly to ''a continuing surge in the number of Hispanic laborers with no health insurance.''

docs.lead_paragraph: Employer health plans across the country are forcing millions of consumers to change their drug-buying habits. And one side effect could be the decline of the neighborhood drugstore. Instead of picking up their medicines at a local pharmacy, growing numbers of consumers will be required -- starting this month when new health plans take effect -- to buy dozens of widely used drugs, like insulin for diabetes or Lipitor to lower cholesterol, by mail order.

headline.main: Drugstores Fret as Insurers Demand Pills by Mail

docs.abstract: Employer health plans across country are forcing millions of consumers to change their drug-buying habits; one side effect could be decline of neighborhood drugstore; growing numbers of consumers, starting in Jan when new health plans take effect, will be required to buy dozens of drugs by mail order; employers and companies that manage prescription drug insurance coverage favor mail-order pharmacies because they can get lucrative rebates and deep discounts from drug makers when they buy in volume; savings, which amount to hundreds of millions of dollars a year, can then be shared with employers and health plans; photos (M)
docs.snippet: Many people will soon be required to receive their drugs by mail order so their employers can get lucrative rebates and deep discounts.
